item.title: 7/26: CBS Weekend News
item.description: Demonstrators protest Trump’s visit to Scotland ahead of U.S.-EU trade talks; California artist brings Bob's Big Boy statues back to life.

item.title: "48 Hours" show schedule
item.description: True crime. Real justice. To miss it would be a crime.

item.title: Did former ballerina accused of murder shoot husband in self-defense?
item.description: To some, Ashley Benefield is a woman who fought back from alleged abuse. To others, she's a manipulative murderer who shot her husband so she would not have to share custody of their daughter.

item.title: "Black Swan" defendant had a gun in her bra the night she met her husband
item.description: There were three loaded guns in her house the night former ballerina Ashley Benefield shot and killed her estranged husband Doug Benefield.

item.title: What led a former ballerina to fatally shoot her husband?
item.description: Ashley Benefield, dubbed the "Black Swan," took the stand in her own defense during her trial for the murder of her estranged husband. Prosecutors say she killed Doug Benefield so she would have sole custody of their daughter.

item.title: The Case of the Black Swan (Part 2)
item.description: The former ballerina dubbed "The Black Swan” tells her story of why she shot and killed her estranged husband. "48 Hours" contributor Jim Axelrod reports in the second part of a two-part "48 Hours."

item.title: The Case of the Black Swan (Part 1)
item.description: A former ballerina shoots her husband. Did she kill to save herself or was it out of spite? "48 Hours" contributor Jim Axelrod reports in part one of a two-part "48 Hours."

item.title: "48 Hours" Live to Tell: The Vendetta
item.description: A judge and her son are ambushed in front of their home. Shot multiple times, the judge refuses to be intimidated and works to stop other attacks. CBS News' Jim Axelrod reports.

item.title: American Airlines jet at Denver International evacuated due to landing gear incident
item.description: Video posted to social media showed passengers evacuating the aircraft using a slide as smoke and flames billowed from below the rear of the plane.

item.title: 11 wounded in stabbing attack at Michigan Walmart, police say; suspect in custody
item.description: Officials said the stabbings happened near the checkout area of the store and appeared to be random in nature.

item.title: 7/22: CBS Evening News Plus
item.description: Video shows conditions inside New York City immigrant detention facility; Reporter's Notebook: Examining the 4-day workweek

item.title: This week on "Sunday Morning" (July 27)
item.description: A look at the features for this week's broadcast of the Emmy-winning program, hosted by Jane Pauley.

item.title: Israeli military says it has begun airdrops of aid into Gaza
item.description: For months, the U.N. and experts have warned that Palestinians in Gaza are at risk of famine, with reports of increasing numbers of people dying from causes related to malnutrition.

item.title: Trump plays golf in Scotland amid nationwide protests
item.description: Hundreds of demonstrators gathered on the cobblestone and tree-lined street in front of the U.S. Consulate in Edinburgh, Scotland's capital.

item.title: How nanoplastics may be impacting our long-term health
item.description: Scientists believe microscopic particles, called nanoplastics, come from all the plastic people use and throw away. When plastic breaks down over time, it winds up in the food supply, the water we drink, and even the air we breathe.

item.title: What to know about the U.S. Postal Service's past, possible future
item.description: The USPS is celebrating with two new commemorative stamps and a celebration at the Smithsonian on July 26.

item.title: CBS News investigates alleged gangs within the Los Angeles Sheriff's Department
item.description: CBS News takes a closer look at allegations that gangs are operating within the Los Angeles Sheriff's Department. CBS News contributor María Elena Salinas speaks to several families who claim the so-called "Banditos" gang killed their sons as part of an initiation into the clique. Then, CBSN's Tanya Rivero speaks to two experts about the history of allegations of gangs in the department, and how Latinos are often misrepresented in the criminal justice system.

item.title: California artist brings Bob's Big Boy statues back to life
item.description: Sheila Lehman is a restoration artist who, over the last year, has refurbished both of the 7-foot Big Boy statues from the iconic Burbank, California, burger restaurant entirely by hand. Joy Benedict reports.

item.title: The impact of nanoplastics on long-term health
item.description: Scientists believe microscopic particles, called nanoplastics, come from all the plastic people use and throw away. When plastic breaks down over time, it winds up in the food supply, the water we drink, and even the air we breathe. Dr. Céline Gounder reports.

item.title: Bipartisan lawmakers reup immigration bill amid Trump deportation crackdown
item.description: A bipartisan group of lawmakers has reintroduced the Dignity Act, which could allow certain undocumented immigrants a chance to earn legal status. Nikole Killion has more.

item.title: Parents rush to buy school supplies before tariff deadline
item.description: The National Retail Federation says more parents than ever are bracing for price hikes and are trying to get ahead of the Aug. 1 tariff deadline by shopping for school supplies in the middle of summer. Ali Bauman has more.

item.title: Israel says airdrops of aid into Gaza will begin Saturday amid increased starvation deaths
item.description: The Israeli military said Saturday that it will resume aid airdrops into Gaza and open humanitarian corridors for United Nations convoys amid increased international pressure and accounts of starvation-related deaths in the territory. Haley Ott reports.

item.title: Demonstrators protest Trump's visit to Scotland ahead of U.S.-EU trade talks
item.description: Protesters gathered in front of the U.S. consulate in Edinburgh to oppose President Trump's visit to Scotland. Mr. Trump plans to host the U.K.'s Prime Minister Keir Starmer and the President of the European Union, Ursula von der Leyen, for trade talks at his personal properties. Weijia Jiang has the latest.

item.title: Chinese research ship detected off Alaskan coast, Coast Guard says
item.description: The Xue Long 2, an icebreaker, is operated by China's Polar Research Institute.

item.title: Woman caught trying to sneak turtles in her bra, TSA says
item.description: The TSA said one turtle died and another was handed off to Florida wildlife officials.

item.title: More than 20% of NASA's workforce requests to leave agency
item.description: About 3,870 employees have applied to depart NASA over two rounds through the Trump administration's deferred resignation program, the agency disclosed.

item.title: Tariffs will drive up U.S. prices even with Trump trade deals, experts say
item.description: With the Trump administration setting 15% as a floor for tariffs, companies and economists are warning of higher prices later this year.

item.title: McDonald's will test 10 CosMc's inspired drinks at select restaurants
item.description: McDonald's will bring cold coffees, crafted sodas and other CosMc's-inspired drinks to select stores in a trial run of a new beverages.

item.title: Researchers concerned over rise in teens using AI for friendship
item.description: In a new survey, 31% of teens said their conversations with AI companions were "as satisfying or more satisfying" than talking with real friends.

item.title: Woman thought she had a pulled muscle working out. It was a rare cancer.
item.description: Jennifer Frederick didn't understand why she had a growing lump under her skin. A doctor returned a devastating diagnosis.
